title: R Ladies Boulder Meetup #4: Ugly Holiday Plot Contest!
description:
Hi Boulder UseRs! Join us for this holiday edition of R Ladies: Ugly Holiday Plot Contest!

This extRa special Meetup is a chance for you to let your holiday enthusiasm loose and share with us your ugliest holiday-themed plots. We will also be at a special location: North Boulder Upslope Brewing Company!

*****Please submit your ugly holiday plots to boulder@rladies.org by December 9th to be included in the ugly plot contest!***** Those without ugly plot submissions are also welcome to attend! All are encouraged to wear ugly holiday attire. For inspiration: reddit.com/r/DataIsUgly/.

During the meeting we will be showing off all of the lovely ugly plot submissions with the option for submitters to say a few words about their plots if they want! Winners will be selected by categories (think: "most likely to make somebody lose their eyesight" or "most variables plotted at once").

Refreshments graciously provided by SomaLogic.

Can't wait to see you all there!

title: R Ladies Boulder Meetup #3: Introduction to Building R Packages
description:
Hi Boulder UseRs! Join us for this month's R Ladies Meetup: How to build a package!

This month our very own Leigh Alexander will be giving us a tutorial on how to build an R package from the ground up. Package ideas are not required, but are definitely encouraged. All skill levels are of course welcome.

** Please bring your laptops!**

5:45-6:00pm - Arrival and mingling
6:00-7:00pm - Package building with Leigh
7:00-7:15pm - Wrap up

Venue and refreshments graciously provided by SomaLogic.

Can't wait to see you all there!

title: R Ladies Boulder Meetup #2: TidyTuesday
description:
Hi Boulder UseRs! Join us for this month's R Ladies Meetup: TidyTuesday!

We plan to participate in TidyTuesday, which is a fun, low-stress coding challenge posted weekly by the R4DS online learning community.

** Please bring your laptops!**

The goal of TidyTuesday is to flex your tidyverse muscles for data wrangling and plotting. However, if you're new to tidyverse (or a die-hard base R useR), you are also more than welcome to join! This is a chance to learn from more experienced tidyverse useRs and make new connections at the same time.

For more information on TidyTuesday, see here: https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday

5:45-6:00pm - Arrival and mingling
6:00-6:15pm - Introductions & instructions
6:15-7:15pm - TidyTuesday group coding challenge!

Venue and refreshments graciously provided by SomaLogic.

Can't wait to see you all there!

title: R-Ladies-Boulder Kickoff Meeting!
description:
Hi Boulder useRs! We're excited to get the paRty started with our official kickoff meeting!

We plan to introduce the organizers of the group and, more importantly, get to know all of you, how you use R, and what'd you love to see from this group.

Each organizer (Courtney, Lisa, Marta, and Leigh) will also briefly present a fun and/or useful R package created by a women, so we can all learn something while getting to know each other. So bring your thoughts, ideas, and enthusiasm! You can bet we will.

5:45-6:00pm - Arrival and mingling
6:00-7:00pm - Introductions and presentations
7:00-7:30pm - Wrap up and more mingling

Venue and refreshments graciously provided by SomaLogic.

Can't wait to see you all soon!

title: R Ladies Boulder Meetup #12: Introduction to Flexdashboards
description:
Hi Boulder UseRs! Join us for this month's **Virtual** R Ladies Meetup and join our new local Slack workspace (https://forms.gle/j36YGxuNwN6zZ8nW7)!

This month, Hilary Traut will be guiding us through the basics of flexdashboard. Flexdashboards are a widely useful method (based in R Markdown) for presenting interactive analysis reports, usually focusing on graphs or other types of data visuals. Hilary will go over the basic components of a flexdashboard, how to create your first flexdashboard using R Markdown, and ideas for how to use them effectively. After an introduction to the tool, Hilary will guide us through creating a flexdashboard using COVID-19 data.

We will be meeting over Zoom (Meeting link visible when you RSVP). Join us to connect with other R users in the Boulder area and learn some new techniques to apply in your work!

We hope you'll also join our local Slack workspace to keep the R help and conversation flowing! To get access to the Slack workspace, please fill out this short Google form: https://forms.gle/j36YGxuNwN6zZ8nW7.

title: R Ladies Boulder Meetup #11: Unsupervised clustering methods in R
description:
Hi Boulder UseRs! Join us for this month's **Virtual** R Ladies Meetup and join our new local Slack workspace (https://forms.gle/j36YGxuNwN6zZ8nW7)!

This month, Dr. Marta Jankowska will be showing us the ropes of some common machine learning algorithms in R. She will focus on unsupervised clustering methods.

Clustering methods are a set of unsupervised learning techniques to identify subgroups within a larger population. These methods are broadly useful as a first step for exploring high dimensional datasets. Two of the most popular methods are K-means and Hierarchical clustering. She will review the theory behind the methods, and work through two example applications in R.

We will be meeting over Zoom (Meeting link visible when you RSVP). Join us to connect with other R users in the Boulder area and learn some new techniques to apply in your work!

We hope you'll also join our local Slack workspace to keep the R help and conversation flowing! To get access to the Slack workspace, please fill out this short Google form: https://forms.gle/j36YGxuNwN6zZ8nW7.

title: R Ladies Boulder Meetup #10: Virtual Meet-n-Greet and Lightning Talks
description:
Hi Boulder UseRs! Join us for this month's **Virtual** R Ladies Meetup and join our new local Slack workspace!

We're hosting a virtual meet-n-greet featuring three great lightning talks.
We will be meeting over Zoom (Meeting link visible when you RSVP). Join us to connect with other R users in the Boulder area and listen into some great informal short talks!

We are planning to do new introductions to get new attendees acquainted with the community and then move on to our lightning talks!

Talk #1: Using R to design an accent wall (Speaker: Leigh Alexander)
Talk #2: Using patchwork to make composite plots (Speaker: Courtney Van Den Elzen)
Talk #3: Teaching R to undergraduates (Speaker: Kelly Carscadden)

We hope you'll join us on Zoom and on our local Slack workspace to keep the R help and conversation flowing! To get access to the Slack workspace, please fill out this short Google form: https://forms.gle/j36YGxuNwN6zZ8nW7

title: R Ladies Boulder Meetup #9: Lightning Talks!
description:
Hi Boulder UseRs! Join us for this month's virtual R Ladies Meetup: Lightning Talks!

Have a cool R project you've been working on? Want to talk about your research or work that uses R? We are currently accepting 5-10 min lightning talk submissions for this virtual Meetup!

This is a great opportunity to get low-stress practice with speaking to diverse audiences about your work. We are also happy to workshop talks with folks if that's of interest.

To submit a lightning talk, please email boulder@rladies.org with a few details about your presentation and whether you'd be interested in workshopping it with us.

Talk details and zoom meeting details TBD.

title: R Ladies Boulder Meetup #8: Virtual Happy Hour
description:
Hi Boulder UseRs! We want to reconnect with all of you! Join us for this month's **Virtual** R Ladies Happy Hour and join our new local Slack workspace!

We're hosting a virtual happy hour and meet-n-greet over Zoom (meeting ID 920 9713 0620). We are also starting a local R Ladies Boulder Slack workspace! These formats provide a unique opportunity to connect with other R users in the Boulder area through virtual introductions, breakout rooms, messaging, and group activities.

During the Zoom happy hour, we're planning to do both re-introductions and new introductions for those of you who have not attended an R Ladies Boulder in-person meetup. We are also planning a fun game and time for one on one and small group conversations in breakout rooms.

We hope you'll join us on Zoom and on Slack! To get access to the Slack workspace, please fill out this short Google form: https://forms.gle/j36YGxuNwN6zZ8nW7

title: R Ladies Boulder Meetup #7: Introduction to R Shiny
description:
**NOTE: The parking lot rules have changed at SomaLogic. Please park on the street or in the lot behind the building R Ladies is hosted in (2990 Wilderness Place) to avoid being booted or towed.**

Hi Boulder UseRs! Join us for this month's R Ladies Meetup: Introduction to R Shiny!

** Please bring your laptops & cash for beer donations!**

This month our very own Lisa Moller will be giving us a tutorial on how to build an R Shiny app from scratch. Lisa has been learning Shiny over the last few months and she's excited to share what she's learned with us!

If you've never used Shiny before or have only dabbled, this tutorial is for you! Experienced Shiny users are also encouraged to attend and share your knowledge with the group as we work through the tutorial.

5:45-6:00pm - Arrival and mingling
6:00-7:00pm - Intro to Shiny with Lisa
7:00-7:15pm - Wrap up

Venue and refreshments graciously provided by SomaLogic, **Beverages by donation.**

Can't wait to see you all there!

title: R Ladies Boulder Meetup #6: Bring Your Own Code Coding Hour
description:
Hi Boulder UseRs! Join us for this month's R Ladies Meetup: Bring Your Own Code Open Coding Hour!

This month we are hosting an open coding night at The Rayback Collective. This is a casual meetup for people to bring their projects, practice skills, and just mingle and share tips, tricks, and expeRtise. Use this time to work through R tutorials, a TidyTuesday challenge, or your own project.

We'll be there by 5:45pm and people are welcome to hang out until Rayback closes.

Can't wait to see you all there!

title: RLadies-Boulder #21: Ugly Plot Contest with Palmer Penguins!!
description:
It's that time of year again...the time for ugly sweaters and ugly plots! Join us Dec 14th on Zoom to create and share your most hideous plots creations. Participants are free to prepare unsightly figures ahead of time or during the meeting. Folks are also free to use their own data or to use this year's adorable (and well curated!) theme data set: Palmer Penguins! Who doesn't want to create unreadable line plots for these cute little guys? (You can install it as a package for easy plot abominations:  ).

Come join in the virtual fun! The victor gets bragging rights for a whole calendar year.

ZOOM PASSWORD WILL BE POSTED IN MEET-UP DISCUSSION DAY OF. (We promise)

title: RLadies Boulder #20: Reproducible Code & Visualization Best Practices
description: Welcome back to another edition of RLadies Boulder! This week, Lara Southard, PhD will walk us through Reproducible Code (including the Project Template library) and Visualization Best Practices. Lara is a Sr. Research Scientist at Pearson and has her PhD in Cognitive Neuroscience from CSU.

title: RLadies Boulder Meetup #19: Happy Hour Round 2 at Sanitas Brewing!
description:
Hi Boulder UseRs! Join us another *in person* R Ladies Boulder Meet-up! We are hosting an informal happy hour get-together at Sanitas Brewing in Boulder. This is our first in-person event post pandemic and we would love to see all of you!

We will be outdoors on the Sanitas patio with R Ladies name tags so you can find us! This is a friendly group of people and the more the merrier so please join us if you feel comfortable. All are welcome!

We hope you'll also join our local Slack workspace to keep the R help and conversation flowing! To get access to the Slack workspace, please fill out this short Google form: https://forms.gle/j36YGxuNwN6zZ8nW7.

title: RLadies #18: Frequentist & Bayesian random effects models in R: RStan tutorial
description:
This month's guest speaker Amanda Koepke will present on random effects modeling in RStan:

A common problem in science, medicine, and other fields is the need to combine independent measurements (taken over multiple days, or at different labs, or using different measurement methods) into a consensus estimate in a way that recognizes explicitly the contributions that different sources of uncertainty (i.e., within-study uncertainties and between-study differences) make to the overall uncertainty. Many methods exist for this, and past studies have compared the performance of different estimation approaches, however little attention has been paid to Bayesian approaches. In this talk, I will briefly describe my work extending these estimator comparisons to Bayesian models and exploring which approaches are best for common data scenarios at NIST (https://www.nist.gov/). I will then give a short tutorial on how to implement this type of Bayesian analysis in R using RStan. The Hamiltonian Monte Carlo used in RStan provides a very efficient way to explore the posterior distribution and allows for the most natural definition of specialized probability distributions. However, it can be tricky to consistently obtain valid samples when trying to fit many simulated datasets with realistic simulation settings. I'll describe some of the issues I encountered and how to deal with some common RStan warnings.

title: RLadies Boulder Meetup #17: From csv to slippy map - intro to spatial data in R
description:
Hi Boulder UseRs! Join us for this month's virtual R Ladies Meetup! This month, Anna Spiers will be giving us an introduction to spatial data and map-making in R!

From Anna: Working with spatial data can feel as finicky as caring for your favorite houseplant - your attempts to help are rejected despite following instructions, and you look longingly at friends' and colleagues' masterpieces (i.e., maps/plants). This talk will introduce spatial data broadly, and cover some of the basic workflows and troubleshooting steps in R. Specifically, we will work with vector data, focus on the `sp` and `sf` libraries, and produce an interactive map in R. Example data and code will be provided.

We will be meeting over Zoom (Meeting link visible when you RSVP). Join us to connect with other R users in the Boulder area and learn some new techniques to apply in your work!

We hope you'll also join our local Slack workspace to keep the R help and conversation flowing! To get access to the Slack workspace, please fill out this short Google form: https://forms.gle/j36YGxuNwN6zZ8nW7.

title: R Ladies Boulder Meetup #14: RStudio 2021 Conference Talk Watch Party
description:
Hi Boulder UseRs! Join us for this month's virtual R Ladies Meetup! We are having an RStudio 2021 Conference talk watch party with four different video options (see below). You choose your video adventure! We will use breakout groups to watch and discuss each video in small groups. This allows for a tailored R Ladies experience and is also a great chance to network with others interested in the same topic!

The videos we will be watching are:
(1) Always Look on the Bright Side of Plots by Kara Woo
(2) Humanitarian Data Science with R by Ahmadou Dicko
(3) The Dynamic Duo: SQL & R by Irene Steves
(4) Art Lessons: Art Lessons: One Year as RStudioâ€™s Artist-in-Residence by Allison Horst

We will be meeting over Zoom (Meeting link visible when you RSVP). Join us to connect with other R users in the Boulder area and learn some new techniques to apply in your work!

We hope you'll also join our local Slack workspace to keep the R help and conversation flowing! To get access to the Slack workspace, please fill out this short Google form: https://forms.gle/j36YGxuNwN6zZ8nW7.

description:
Hi Boulder UseRs! We are back in action next month after our hiatus! Join us for a virtual R Ladies Meetup where Dr. Marta Jankowska will be giving a tutorial on Elastic Net, Ridge, and Lasso Regression approaches!
Please stay tuned for more details on Dr. Jankowska's tutorial.

We will be meeting over Zoom (Meeting link visible when you RSVP). Join us to connect with other R users in the Boulder area and learn some new techniques to apply in your work!

title: RLadies-Boulder #25: Government Data w/ Christina Brady
description:
**The Talk:**
Government data: Use it for research, to hold your government accountable or just for data practice and experimentation. It's free, plenty and messy! I'll walk through some common (and some lesser known) data sets published by the federal government as well as some state and local data sources.

**About the Speaker:**
I have been doing data science-y things including analysis, visualization and some machine learning for about 8 years. I currently do that for the Office of Federal Student Aid in the US Department of Education. My past lives include leading a data team in a small newsroom (hence the knowledge of public data sets) and analyzing, predicting and communicating the health of the World Bank portfolio of projects.

title: RLadies-Boulder #24: rtweet Tutorial!
description:
**SPEAKER:** This online event will be lead by Zane Dax ([https://twitter.com/StarTrek_Lt](https://twitter.com/StarTrek_Lt))! Zane has a BHsci in Public Health, started programming in Python but turned avid R user, and is very active on Twitter. She/They make R hexagon logos for R packages and streams on Twitch for data analysis and data visualizations.
**TOPIC OVERVIEW:** Twitter is a powerful tool and is part of a plethora of social media platforms. Twitter is widely used in the world for data science and research, as well as communication of various data science topics. Being a user is fine, but each tweet captures a lot of data that the user is unaware of - to unlock this hidden information one usually needs to have a Twitter API key to grab all the meta data on every tweet and Twitter user. In this special event, Zane will explain and walk through the rtweet package documentation ([https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/rtweet/rtweet.pdf](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/rtweet/rtweet.pdf)). She/They will provide explained and ready to go examples with the data ready for your own data analysis, such as text analysis from word counts from tweets collected. This is the only Twitter API tutorial that you get to fully enjoy and learn from without any worry about being granted a API key for your data analysis!PREPARATION AND
**RESOURCES:** There is nothing to prepare in advance. The tutorial resources are available on GitHub: [https://github.com/PythonCoderUnicorn/rtweet-tutorial](https://github.com/PythonCoderUnicorn/rtweet-tutorial)

title: RLadies #22: Frequentist & Bayesian Random Effects Models in R: RStan Tutorial
description:
This month's guest speaker Amanda Koepke will present on random effects modeling in RStan:

A common problem in science, medicine, and other fields is the need to combine independent measurements (taken over multiple days, or at different labs, or using different measurement methods) into a consensus estimate in a way that recognizes explicitly the contributions that different sources of uncertainty (i.e., within-study uncertainties and between-study differences) make to the overall uncertainty. Many methods exist for this, and past studies have compared the performance of different estimation approaches, however little attention has been paid to Bayesian approaches. In this talk, I will briefly describe my work extending these estimator comparisons to Bayesian models and exploring which approaches are best for common data scenarios at NIST (https://www.nist.gov/). I will then give a short tutorial on how to implement this type of Bayesian analysis in R using RStan. The Hamiltonian Monte Carlo used in RStan provides a very efficient way to explore the posterior distribution and allows for the most natural definition of specialized probability distributions. However, it can be tricky to consistently obtain valid samples when trying to fit many simulated datasets with realistic simulation settings. I'll describe some of the issues I encountered and how to deal with some common RStan warnings.

title: R-Ladies Boulder #27: Integrating R & Google Workspaces w/ Jade Yonehiro
description:
"As data analysts, we often collaborate with colleagues on analyses and data presentations who do not have R or other statistical programming skill sets. These collaborations can be frustrating for both the analyst and non-analyst, with the analyst needing to make and remake tables or visuals and the non-analyst lacking the autonomy to tweak or explore data themselves. One open access and open source based solution is to develop workflows between R and more accessible programs such as Excel or Google Sheets. The googlesheets4 package provides analysts a linking tool so they can leverage the power of R for data processing and visualization while empowering non-analysts with a user-friendly environment for collaboration."

Zoom link for remote attendees: https://us02web.zoom.us/j/85471235979?pwd=a3FBRWpubysxcDYzS1FvZlhEWVlHZz09

title: RLadies-Boulder #26: sparklyr - A Simple Guide w/ Hilary Traut
description:
**SAVE THE DATE!**
R Ladies is back after a hiatus and we are meeting in person at Solid State Depot in Boulder! We would love to see you all, get back together, socialize, and listen to Hilary's talk: sparklyr - A Simple Guide.

Ex-academic and current corporate nerd-for-hire Hilary Traut will provide a step-by-step guide to understanding Apache Spark in R. She'll tackle such existential questions as:

* What is Spark? What is it good for?
* When is Spark the tool for me?
* How to "spark" a connection to R
* Using dplyr and friends to simplify your spark modeling pipeline

Bring a laptop to follow along in real time, or just yourself to sit back and enjoy the presentation. Live coding mishaps practically guaranteed!
